gold_answer: A financial advisor is a professional service provider who can handle tasks that you either don't have time for or prefer someone else to manage. If you lack the time or interest to manage your investments, hiring a financial advisor is a good idea. It's generally better to work with an advisor who charges an annual fee based on a percentage of your account value rather than one who gets paid based on transactions. Advisors compensated in the latter way may have a vested interest in making frequent changes to your account, which might not be in your best interest. It's important to be cautious of advisors who promote expensive mutual funds with sales loads or annuities. Additionally, your advisor's compensation structure should be transparent.

retrieved_contexts.text: If you don't have the time or interest to manage investments, you need a financial advisor.  Generally speaking, you're better served by an advisor who collects an annual fee based on a percentage of your account value. Advisors who are compensated based on transactions have a vested interest to churn your account, which is often not in your best interest. You also need to be wary of advisors who peddle expensive mutual funds with sales loads (aka kick-backs to the advisor) or annuities. Your advisor's compensation structure should be transparent as well.

ml.tokens.model_text: Does a business owner needs a financial advisor?

retrieved_contexts.text: A financial advisor is a service professional.  It is his/her job to do things for you that you could do for yourself, but you're either too busy to do it yourself (and you want to pay somebody else), or you'd rather not. Just like some people hire tax preparers, or maids, or people to change their oil, or re-roof their houses. Me, I choose to self-manage.  I get some advise from Fidelity and Vanguard.  But we hired somebody this year to re-roof our house and someone else to paint it.
